presentation.title: Carbon assessment
presentation.runninghead: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 capture
presentation.description: The values accrued by any beneficiary of CO2 capture

page.name: CO2 assessment
page.title: General description
page.description:
This storyline computes statistics of carbon sequestration by terrestrial ecosystems, intended as the net removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere or the avoidance of CO2 emissions from terrestrial ecosystems into the atmosphere. The removal process includes CO2 uptake from the atmosphere by all chlorophyllous plants, through photosynthesis. This carbon (C) is stored as plant biomass (in the trunks, branches, leaves and roots of the plants) and organic matter in the soil. Terrestrial carbon sequestration depends on a series of factors including climatic conditions, vegetation structure and successional stage, and land use practices.

In ARIES, we distinguish between ecosystem sources of carbon sequestration capacity capable of removing CO2 from the atmosphere and storing carbon in vegetation and soils. We also map sinks, or areas that release stored carbon, largely via fire or deforestation. By subtracting the amount of stored carbon release from carbon sequestration in a region of interest, we are left with the carbon remaining available to offset anthropogenic emissions. In this storyline, gas emitters are conceptualized as the beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage. Since greenhouse gas emitters benefit from the waste absorption capacity of the biosphere, carbon sequestration and storage can be divided among emitters. Existing and proposed systems to cap and assign property rights to atmospheric greenhouse gas emissions use this framework. In other words:

Carbon sequestration (source) – stored carbon release (sink) = carbon available to offset emissions (use)

By mapping levels of carbon sequestration, stored carbon release, and anthropogenic emissions in a common unit (tonnes C/ha.yr), we can fully describe regional carbon balances – the level of a region’s net release or uptake of atmospheric CO2. This will become increasingly important as local, state, and national governments continue to inventory greenhouse gas emissions and implement strategies to address climate change. Use of carbon sequestration is rival and occurs at the global scale through atmospheric mixing.
page.see-also:
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
IPCC web site
page.credits:
Model and data development: Ken Bagstad, Ferdinando Villa, Gary Johnson, Sergey Krivov, Brian Voigt.
Additional contributors: Ted Auch, Mark Casias, Sam Gorton, Jennifer Wright, Dave Batker, Jim Pittman, Paula Swedeen. Miroslav Honzak.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Total Sequestration
page.name: C removed
page.description:
Total CO2 sequestered. The amount of carbon taken up by vegetation and soils and added to biotic and soil carbon stocks. This is the quantity available for mitigating anthropogenic carbon emissions.

Role in models

This map is the most relevant output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of climate change is directly proportional to the level of carbon sequesterd by vegetation and soil.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbons sequestered per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the distribution probability of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server when the area was selected.
page.see-also:
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
IPCC web site
page.runninghead: Tonnes of C sequestered by vegetation and soils

page.name: C Released
page.title: Release of stored carbon
page.description:
The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change.

Role in models

This map is an output of the ARIES carbon model. The value of the area in mitigating the adverse effects of climate change is negatively affected by large amounts of carbon released.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbons released per hectare per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the distribution probability of the amount of carbon. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server when the area was selected.
page.runninghead: The total emissions of carbon from the landscape, i.e., due to fire, deforestation, or other land use-land cover change.

page.name: C Emitted
page.title: CO2 emission from human activity
page.description:
The beneficiaries of carbon sequestration and storage are greenhouse gas emitters who release CO2 into the atmosphere, relying on ecosystems to absorb and store carbon in order to avoid even larger rises in atmospheric CO2 than are currently seen. Our carbon use models thus displays greenhouse gas emissions.

Role in models

This map is used to identify the beneficiaries of CO2 sequestration in this storyline.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tonnes of carbons sequestered per hectare per year.

Source

Spatially explicit data on greenhouse gas emissions exist for the United States. Globally, we use population density data multiplied by per capita emissions for the country or sub-national region of interest.
page.runninghead: Emitters benefit under a scenario of compensation

page.title: C/N ratio in soil
page.name: C/N ratio
page.description:
The ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils influences the rate of sequestration of carbon from the vegetation, along with temperature ranges, land cover, vegetation types and evapotranspiration.

Role in models

Data are used as input to the sequestration (source) model.

Representation

Data are a unitless ratio of carbon/nitrogen concentrations.

Source

The data are provided by the global Soil database published by FAO. The latest version of the data, used in this model, is from 1978.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Ratio of carbon to nitrogen in soils

page.name: Temp range
page.title: Summer - Winter temperature range
page.description:
The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures can be a meaningful predictor of net primary production.

Role in models

This map is classified from available temperature records and is used as an input in the ARIES carbon models for both sequestration and release of C. The value of the variable influences the C sequestration and storage rates of the vegetation component.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees centigrades.

Source

This map has been reclassified from globally available data provided by .
T
page.runninghead: The difference between mean summer high and winter low temperatures.

page.title: Successional Stage
page.name: Succession
page.description:
The stage of vegetation regrowth following a major disturbance event. The rate succession will vary widely in different plant communities and regions of the world.

Role in models

.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: The stage of vegetation growth influences CO2 uptake.

page.name: Veg Cover
page.title: Percent vegetative cover
page.description:
Tree canopy data are used to estimate the total percent vegetative cover in an area. This variable influences both total carbon sequestration and soil carbon storage in most environments through vegetation density, which is also dependent, when applicable, on the status of degradation of the vegetation.

Role in models

The variable is used as input to compute carbon sequestration and soil carbon storage distributions, which feed into the calculation of total carbon release (service sink).

Representation

Data are percentage of ground covered by vegetation.

Source

NLCD 2001 data; GLCF (University of Maryland) data used where NLCD database coverage is absent.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Hardwood/Softwood ratio
page.name: Hardwood
page.description:
Softwood and hardwood tree species grow at different rates, so they sequester and store atmospheric carbon in different ways. Data about the ratio of hardwood to softwood species can be extracted from vegetation records and allow modeling this complex biophysical processes using a single variable.

Role in models

The ratio of hardwood to softwood enters the probabilistic model of carbon sequestration.

Representation

.

Source

.
page.see-also: The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Fire
page.title: Fire Frequency
page.description:
Fires, when they happen frequently, are an important and predictable variable in determining release of carbon from biomass. This variable is included only when the fire variable is expected to be a factor in the C balance.
h1. Role in models
h1. Representation
h1. Source

page.name: Population
page.title: Population density
page.description:
Population density influences carbon storage in the ARIES sink model used for this storyline. This influence is only relevant in tropical environments due to the uses being made of the forests.

Role in models

This variable is used as an input to vegetative carbon storage, in the path to computing the probabilistic model of stored carbon release (service sink).

Representation

Gaston et al. (1998) define the discretization used here to model population density effects on carbon levels.

Source

.
page.see-also:
Gaston, G., S. Brown, M. Lorenzini, and K.D. Singh. 1998. State and change in carbon pools in the forests of tropical Africa. Global Change Biology 4: 97-114.
The carbon section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: LANDSCAN 30m coverages produced by Oak Ridge Natl.Labs.
Funding: US National Science Foundation.

page.title: Level of forest degradation
page.name: Degradation
page.description:
Forests can be noted as degraded or not degraded. When that information is available, it can be used to train probabilistic models so that its effect is estimated and taken into consideration when models are used to predict C levels.

Role in models

.

Representation

.

Source

.

Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: Degradation of forests can influence sequestration.

page.name: Vegetation
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different species and groups of plant species have different carbon sequestration rates and different capacity to store carbon.

.

page.name: Oxygen
page.title: Soil oxic conditions
page.description:
The presence of oxygen (aerobic environment) allows respiration to take place, where sugars are oxidized and CO2 is produced. In anaerobic environments, methanogenesis may occur. Falling water tables in wetlands can also allow oxidation of soils, reducing their carbon storage.

Role in models

.

Representation

.

Source

.

page.credits:
Data provided by:
Funding: US National Science Foundation.
page.runninghead: The presence of oxygen allows CO2-producing respiration to take place.

page.name: Deforestation
page.title: Risk of deforestation
page.description:
The risk of deforestation is linked to increasing likelihood of a decrease in carbon sequestration and an increase in carbon release.

Role in models

.

Representation

.

Source
